posts.name: Matthew Dempsky
posts.cooked:
One of my activist groups has been using “only admin can send messages” group chats for sending announcements. We recently created a new announcement group to promote an upcoming action, and have been publicly sharing the “group link” URL. However, now scammers are joining and privately messaging everyone else in the group.

It would be nice if we could limit it so that only admins can see group members.

I can imagine this interferes with the ability for group members to see each other’s reactions to admin messages. A few options that I think would be acceptable for our group, in decreasing order of preference:

  • Continue showing total reaction counts, but redact the “who reacted” lists to only admins and people you’ve chatted with before (e.g., 10 thumbs up, from “Alice, Bob, and 8 other Signal users”)
  • Continue showing total reaction counts, but redact the “who reacted” list entirely
  • Allow admins to see total reaction counts, but non-admins can only see reactions from admins and themselves
  • Disallow reactions in group chats that hide membership

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: One of the few feature requests that I’ve seen on this forum that are well thought out and would be absolute amazing quality of life upgrades for Signal.

The only problem is that there wouldn’t be a way to control that. The Signal server doesn’t handle messages at a level where it knows what they belong to, so the only possible place any kind of “filtering” could be done is on the receiving client side. So they could implement something in the official client, but it would simply be hiding information from the user that they’re “not supposed” to know about, which means any unofficial client could still show the full information.

posts.name: Matthew Dempsky
posts.cooked:
The Signal server doesn’t handle messages at a level where it knows what they belong to

Doesn’t the Signal server have to distinguish admins from non-admins to implement the existing moderation features? E.g., who’s allowed to add/remove people, edit the group settings, and message in restricted groups? Or is all of that implemented client side actually?

mdempsky:

Doesn’t the Signal server have to distinguish admins from non-admins to implement the existing moderation features?

I’m not sure of the implementation details, but the server has no knowledge of who belongs to what group, or if a person is a group admin, or even if a message is a group message or 1-to-1 chat message. Group information is stored on the server, but it’s encrypted and only accessible by members who have the group encryption keys. That would mean it would have to be handled solely by the clients, but I’m not sure of the exact details of how they manage that.

posts.name: link ✦
posts.cooked:
mdempsky:

Doesn’t the Signal server have to distinguish admins from non-admins to implement the existing moderation features? E.g., who’s allowed to add/remove people, edit the group settings, and message in restricted groups?

Regarding everything but “message in restricted groups”, the Signal server can distinguish who is requesting or attempting to change information about the group:

  1. Someone who just has the group link but isn’t a member;
  2. Someone who just has the group link but isn’t a member and is banned from the group;
  3. Someone who requested to join the group using a group link (that requires admin approval before joining) but isn’t a member;
  4. Someone who is invited to the group;
  5. Someone who is a member;
  6. Someone who is a member and has the admin role;
  7. etc.

Due to the design of the group system, it doesn’t know who the user is (it doesn’t know their UUID / phone number / etc.) or the content of the changed information (i.e. the new group description or name), but it does know what role a user must have in order to change certain information and ensures that only that role can actually make the change.

So the server could limit who can see group membership. In fact, it already does this when you request to join the group (cases 1-3 above)—even though the user has the group master key (from the group link) and could decrypt the group member information if it was given to them, the server doesn’t give it to them in the first place (see Beta feedback for the upcoming Android 4.74 release - #17 by alan-signal).

However, when it comes to group messages themselves (and each reaction addition/removal is also technically a “message”), only clients have the necessary information to determine whether the message is from a group admin or not, etc. So it is the sending clients who disallow sending anything but reactions and remote deletion requests (see bottom of "Send messages" permission availability - #4 by awaitlink for source), and the receiving clients who drop any messages that the sender isn’t allowed to send (because the sender could modify the client and send them anyway).

I’m not aware of any way that would currently allow you to send an “anonymous” message to a group without revealing who you are, which seems like what would be necessary for any option that requires showing total reaction counts without showing some or all reacting members:

mdempsky:
  • Continue showing total reaction counts, but redact the “who reacted” lists to only admins and people you’ve chatted with before (e.g., 10 thumbs up, from “Alice, Bob, and 8 other Signal users”)
  • Continue showing total reaction counts, but redact the “who reacted” list entirely

Although the receiving client would still need some persistent per-group user identifier in order to prevent duplicate reactions from the same user, ensure that only the user who added the reaction can remove it, that other users can’t make fake reactions from other users. Basically, there must be 1-1 correspondence between such an identifier and the only Signal user who can use such an identifier, but the receiving client must not be able to tell from the identifier who the corresponding Signal user is.

Of course, these two options could also be implemented in the current system by simply not showing the other Signal users in the UI, but anyone with a modified client would be able to see who they are, so this isn’t really a solution, as mentioned in Permission to limit who can see group membership - #3 by Herohtar.

mdempsky:
  • Allow admins to see total reaction counts, but non-admins can only see reactions from admins and themselves

This should be possible in the current system. If the group is configured to hide membership:

  • Non-admins would only send their reactions to admins (admins will see who the reacting users are);
  • Admins would send reactions to everyone in the group.
mdempsky:
  • Disallow reactions in group chats that hide membership

This is also obviously possible. Sending clients would disallow sending reactions in such groups and receiving clients would drop any reaction messages in such groups (in case someone uses a modified client and still sends a reaction; in that case they also “voluntarily” leak the fact that they sent this reaction, so someone with a modified receiving client can learn that they are in the group and sent this reaction).

Note: I’m using “sending clients” and “receiving clients” to simply refer to the “sending” and “receiving” parts of the Signal apps.

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
It would require a lot of changes, including what to do if the admins switch the “who may send messages” toggle. One if the strenghts of Signal is that it does not distinguise between channels n groups but instead treats verything as a group with a toggle for send permission. for this feature request it means users should have the option to either leave the group or accept deanonimisation when the group send permission is switched to everyone, and also awareness that if you have already shared your profile you can’t go back to full anonimity for existing members.
And what if the admin suddenly makes everyone an admin, to deliberately reveal everyones identify to each other?

This would require major upgrades to how the server handles group membership, but also to how profile sharing and group administration works.

I’d also love to have this feature. I have a group chats specifically for updating various groups of friends & family about various things that affect them.

Essentially, they are solely announcement channels. Only I can post in them. No one else needs to post, and no one else needs to know who else is in the group, because they aren’t interacting with each other.

For improved privacy between my various groups of friends & family, I would love to be able to prevent everyone from seeing each other, including system-generated announcements of who is joining or leaving the group chat.

Additionally, it would be great if we were able to turn off reactions but, even better, if we were able to keep them on without non-admins seeing who reacted.

a. Could the admin be the one that sends the total reaction count to the other users without the actual messages(instead of the server, which doesn’t have this information).
b. To me having a sending list without reaction count would already be an improvement.

posts.name: Busssard
posts.cooked:
if this is too much work, there could be another toggle “hide members until sent message” with a 3way toggle: open, lurk and hidden

Open: All members are always visible

Lurk: this would enable a sort of fog, where Group members only appear on the member list after they have sent a message in the group

closed: nobody is ever visible in the group. All avatars are censored. All messages are anonymous.

All of these would only be anonymous to other users as the signal servers would still be able to identify the users sending messages (which is important for flagging, banning etc)
—

This feature would really make such a big difference for many people that are currently stuck on platforms like telegram.
So if we can help bringing this feature to life, please let us know how!
There is currently another strong push from channels on telegram to bring people to signal, so lets use that momentum.

This feature could be integrated into a granular permission framework like this:

Group level policies Feature Requests
Now that v2 groups are implemented the admin role, I’d like to request a feature set that is a part of my earlier proposal for group administration (link). Group level policies There could be some policy rules that would be applied on every member in the group. These polices would be on/off settings (except the last one) and only admins could set them. This way an admin could customize a group’s behaviour, profile, purpose, also could prevent to overload big groups i.e by forbidding to post …
